evidence.pdf_reference: UV-vis light irradiation (Fig. 7c).Additionally, the Ag content in the used sample AgTiO 2 is about 0.81 wt, which is very close to the Ag content in the fresh sample.This result suggests that the Ag leaching from the catalyst in the photocatalytic CO 2 reduction is almost negligible, which is also the reason for the excellent stability and activity of the catalyst.The excellent recyclability and stability will be of great interest for achieving high-efficiency CO 2 reduction. (route iii), the produced hot plasmonic electrons can further transfer to the TiO 2 nanoparticles or adjacent metal Ag and reduce CO 2 to CO.Therefore, the sample AgTiO 2 shows better performance in the CO 2 reduction compared with the sample TiO 2 , which can be ascribed to the synergetic effects between Ag and TiO 2 .Meanwhile, the photo-induced holes on the TiO 2 would oxidize H 2 O into OH.

The photoelectrochemical tests were conducted in Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) solution on the CHI 660A electrochemical workstation with three electrode system.A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as light source.A Pt sheet and AgAgCl electrode were used as opposite and reference electrode, respectively.In the preparing process of work electrode, 40 mg of catalyst was dispersed into 1 mL ethanol by ultrasonic technique to form a slurry.Next, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on carbon paper with an area of 2

all samples under UV-vis light irradiation are shown in Fig. 7b-c.During the photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 , only gas CO as reduction product can be detected on the samples, while H 2 as byproducts can be not observe.It may be because the catalyst provides a driving force that overcomes the energy barrier of CO 2 reduction to rather than the H 2 evolution, similar to previous report 34.Besides, no products have been detected before photocatalytic reaction, hinting that the product CO is derived from CO

Photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 into high added-value chemical products has received special attention.Herein, we designed a novel hierarchically porous and defective TiO 2 modified by Ag quantum dots via a hydrothermal process assisted with organic surfactant and subsequently in-situ photodeposition method.The obtained Ag quantum dots modified TiO 2 (AgTiO 2 ) shows excellent and stable photocatalytic activity in CO 2 reduction.In addition, the competing H 2 evolution can be completely suppressed.The

The photoelectrochemical tests were conducted in Na 2 SO 4 (0.5 M) solution on the CHI 660A electrochemical workstation with three electrode system.A 300 W Xe lamp was employed as light source.A Pt sheet and AgAgCl electrode were used as opposite and reference electrode, respectively.In the preparing process of work electrode, 40 mg of catalyst was dispersed into 1 mL ethanol by ultrasonic technique to form a slurry.Next, 0.3 mL slurry was coated on carbon paper with an area of 2

carbon paper with an area of 2 cm 2 and dried at 100 C for 4 h. The photocatalytic reduction of CO 2 was measured in an 80 mL gasclosed system under UV-vis light irradiation emitted from a 300 W Xe lamp without any light filter which positioned 10 cm above the reactor.A suspension of catalyst (50 mg) and deionized water (40 mL) was added into the reactor with vigorous stirring.The photoreaction system was purged with the high-purity CO 2 gas for 30 min before the lamp tune on, and the temperature of

water solution, the precipitate was collected after drying at 100 C for 8 h and the final sample was denoted as AgTiO 2 .
